Section 4(b) of Public Law 94-241 is amended to limit payments to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands for fiscal years 1996 and beyond to amounts specified in the Agreement of the Special Representatives on Future Federal Financial Assistance. The additional amounts for capital infrastructure projects in American Samoa, Guam, the Virgin Islands, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Palau, Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands will be made available as specified in subsection (c) of the Agreement. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million will be allocated to the College. In fiscal year 1997, $3 million will be allocated to the College of the Northern Marianas for infrastructure assistance to address immigration, labor, and law enforcement issues in the region. The projects will be outlined in a five-year plan developed by the Secretary of the Interior in consultation with the island governments. The Department of the Interior will prioritize capital infrastructure projects in a five-year plan, considering master plans, Corps of Engineers' reviews, maintenance needs, local cost-share requirements, and proposing an emergency fund of up to $2 million per year for disaster assistance. The emergency fund for repair, replacement, or hardening of essential facilities is capped at $10 million. Additional contributions for the resettlement of Rongelap Atoll are limited to $32 million from any Federal source after January 1, 1995, contingent on a settlement agreement approved by the President. Federal agencies providing assistance in the Republic of the Marshall Islands can make funds available for the resettlement of Rongelap through the Secretary of the Interior. Ex gratia assistance can also be provided for individuals not resettling at Rongelap, once all necessary funds for resettlement are secured. Federal minimum wage. Effective thirty days after enactment, the minimum wage provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act will apply to the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, starting at $2.75 per hour and increasing annually. The minimum wage rate in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands will be adjusted to match the wage rate set forth in section 6(a)(1) of the Fair Labor Standards Act once it reaches that level. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of the Interior, along with other government officials, must submit a report to Congress by March 15 each year detailing the use of funds for immigration, labor, and law enforcement activities in the Commonwealth. The report includes immigration data, such as the number of non-US citizen contract workers in the CNMI, and information on their treatment and conditions. The curr_chunk discusses issues such as the treatment of non-United States citizen contract workers, the impact of laws in the Northern Mariana Islands on Federal interests, the adequacy of detention facilities, the reliability of the alien identification system, and the challenges faced by Federal agencies in enforcing laws in the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will cooperate in identifying and, if necessary, excluding or deporting individuals posing security or law enforcement risks. Additionally, there is a clarification of local employment in the Marianas. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the Immigration and Naturalization Service will cooperate in identifying and excluding individuals posing security risks. Section 8103(i) of title 46 is amended to allow aliens in CNMI to work as unlicensed seamen on vessels within US waters. The amendment allows aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to work as unlicensed seamen on vessels within US waters. SEC. 6. CLARIFICATION OF OWNERSHIP OF SUBMERGED LANDS IN THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE NORTHERN MARIANA ISLANDS. Public Law 93-435 (88 Stat. 1210) is amended by including the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in various sections. References to enactment dates in the law now refer to the date of enactment of this specific section. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress on the economic development, federal assistance, local finances, infrastructure, and financial management of various territories and states. Additionally, a technical correction is included in the law. Section 501 of Public Law 95-134 is amended to include the Republic of Palau, the Republic of the Marshall Islands, and the Federated States of Micronesia. Passed by the Senate on July 20, 1995.
